title: How to Cut Collard Greens

steps.headline: Fill the sink halfway with a solution of lukewarm water and vinegar.
steps.description: Add ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of white vinegar and enough water to cover the number of greens you have. Swish it around with your hands to mix it together. If you are preparing for a party, you can do this in a large washtub as well. Just add a proportional amount of vinegar to the amount of water you need to wash your greens. Some people have reported success in washing greens in the washing machine. It's not practical for most situations and isn't any easier than washing them in the sink, but it is an option if you have a large number of greens and no sink or washtub large enough to handle them.

steps.headline: Soak and swish the greens for about 90 minutes.
steps.description: Submerge the greens in the water and swish them around with your hands to allow the vinegar and water solution to rush over them. Then, let them sit for 10 minutes and swish them around again. Continue doing this for about 90 minutes. You do not need to change out the water. The greens will float while the dirt sinks, keeping them separate.

steps.headline: Remove and rinse the greens, one at a time.
steps.description: Take each leaf separately out of the dirty water solution and rinse it well with cold water as you remove it. Run your hands gently over the leaves as you rinse them to make sure you are getting all the dirty water off of them. If you feel any grit on the leaves, rub it off under running water.

steps.headline: Drain the water from the leaves in a large colander.
steps.description: Lay the leaves in a large colander to allow the water to drip away while you clean the sink or prepare the rest of the meal. If you do not have a colander large enough, you can lay them out on clean towels on the counter. It's not necessary to dry the leaves well before you cut and cook them. If you want to get to work right away, just shake off the water before you began preparing them.

steps.headline: Pull the leaves off the stems with your hands for a quick solution.
steps.description: Once you are done with cleaning the leaves, you can remove the stems. For this, hold the leaf, stem side up, tightly in one hand. With the other hand, pinch the stem where the leaf begins between your thumb and forefinger. Then, squeeze your thumb and forefinger together, dragging downward, to remove the leaf from the stem. If it doesn’t come off in one big piece, just pick the leftover scraps off the stem. You don’t want to waste any of those delicious leaves!

steps.headline: Fold each leaf in half and trim the stem with a knife to get the most precise cut.
steps.description: Lay the leaf on your cutting surface so the exposed part of the stem is on the bottom. Then, fold the leaf in half lengthwise at the stem, so the hard stem faces outward on the left edge. Finally, take your knife and trace along the stem to cut the leaf off of it. If you have several greens that are roughly the same size, fold each in half, then stack the folded leaves and trim them.

steps.headline: Lay a few leaves flat on your cutting surface and destem them if you have a lot.
steps.description: Make a neat pile of 3 or 4 leaves by lining up the stems so they closely overlap. It's easiest if you lay them face down, so the stem is exposed on the top where you can see it. Then, take a sharp knife and slice around the stems in a narrow triangular shape, separating them from the leaves. While you can cut several at once this way, you will probably have to do more work to pull the extras off the stem because stacking them doesn’t allow you to get very close to the stems.

steps.headline: Roll up the greens like a cigar and cut them into shreds for thin slices.
steps.description: Stack 6-8 destemmed leaves into a pile on your cutting board so the long side of the leaves are facing you. Then, simply pinch the edge of the stack on the side closest to you and roll the whole thing tightly into a cigar-shaped bundle. To cut, simply hold the bundle tightly with one hand and make cuts in the greens from one end to the other. How thick you slice them is up to you. This cut will produce ribbon-like greens that are long and thin. Some people like very thin ribbons, which will cook up faster and softer than larger, bite-sized chunks. Check your recipe if you are unsure which to use for you case. This method, called chiffonade, is also used for cutting fresh herbs like basil. You can use any sharp kitchen knife for this method, though a standard chef's knife will work best.

steps.headline: Stack several leaves together and rough chop them for most recipes.
steps.description: Because you are going to cook the greens down and make them soft, they will not maintain their shape. Therefore, it’s not really necessary to create perfect cuts. A quick and easy way to chop several leaves at once is to stack 6-8 leaves and roughly chop them into 1 inch (2.5 cm) bites. A small kitchen knife will not work for this method because the leaves tend to be so big. Choose a standard chef's knife with at least an 8 inches (20 cm) blade for the best and easiest results.

steps.headline: Rip up the leaves into bite-size pieces with your hands for an easy option.
steps.description: For centuries, collard greens have been cut by simply ripping them. Just grab a hold of a handful of leaves with one hand and tear bite-sized pieces off with the other. They will rip easily and the actual size and shape don’t really matter for most recipes.
